qas.question: What are many long distance migrants genetically programmed to do?
How do species that move short distances know when to migrate?
Why do mountain and moorland breeders move only altitudinally?

answers.text: to escape the cold higher ground

qas.question: Where do the merlin Falco columbarius migrate to?

answers.text: the coast or towards the south

qas.question: How far do British chaffinch more in their lives?

context: Many long-distance migrants appear to be genetically programmed to <a0_0>respond to changing day length<a0_0/>. Species that move short distances, however, may not need such a timing mechanism, instead moving in <a1_0>response to local weather conditions<a1_0/>. Thus mountain and moorland breeders, such as wallcreeper Tichodroma muraria and white-throated dipper Cinclus cinclus, may move only altitudinally <a2_0>to escape the cold higher ground<a2_0/>. Other species such as merlin Falco columbarius and Eurasian skylark Alauda arvensis move further, to <a3_0>the coast or towards the south<a3_0/>. Species like the chaffinch are much less migratory in Britain than those of continental Europe, mostly not moving more than <a4_0>5 km<a4_0/> in their lives.
